Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: <@U033SL06X> <@U5Z26MP60> <@U8WFL9AMU> it‚Äôs due to the way `marketmaker` handles sell orders. Basically sell orders don‚Äôt exist, everything is a buy. If we tell mm to place a sell it just flips the values and places a buy on the inverse pair

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: It is technically correct, we are displaying the correct trade data according to mm

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: but I agree it is confusing

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: more info here:

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: https://github.com/lukechilds/hyperdex/issues/184

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: https://github.com/lukechilds/hyperdex-bugtracker/issues/15

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: You can see the discussion there why we chose to display it like we are

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: TLDR; it would be possible to show these as sell order in the way you expect, but we decided against that because it would literally mean showing incorrect data, just because it‚Äôs more intuitive.

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: an excerpt from the issue

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: >We obviously want to hide as much of the complexity as possible from the user, but completely faking the order book value just to make it seem more intuitive is too far IMO. As far as marketmaker is concerned KMD/REVS orders are not REVS/KMD orders.

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: If you think this is the wrong choice and we should fake the trading pair buy/sell action for usability, feel free to make your case over on the GitHub issue, it will get lost in Slack

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: cc <@U064HEB7Y>: you might be interested in this discussion too ‚òù

Author: pondsea#0000
Content: https://twitter.com/HyperDEXApp/status/1001252655237246976 Luke working his magic

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: Technically KMD/ETH not ETH/KMD üòâ

Author: blackjok3r#0000
Content: <@U7B8VF6TB> I think its fine to leave it like that as the top of the trade shows correct, but it also seems very confusing the first time its encountered. My self, with BarterDEX GUI once I got use to flipping pairs, I always did it that way so I was always buying and the price was always the larger number, so I didnt have to deal with huge decimals. But it took weeks of playing around and making mistakes to get used to it. As far as I am aware you are already flipping pairs to always be Alice anyway in hyperDEX so maybe you should just inverse these numbers. 1/x should work fine, thats  the formula I used to flip pairs and never went wrong using it.

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: We don‚Äôt flip any pairs and you are always Alice anyway

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: it was misleading because in the API docs there are buy and sell commands

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: so we built the exchange with buy/sell functionality

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: but after testing it a bit more and wondering why we were getting weird responses from sell commands we realised that mm was just inverting the pair and changing them to buys

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: had we known that from the start we‚Äôd probably of only added buy functionality and required the user to flip the pair to ‚Äúsell‚Äù

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: but to clarify, we don‚Äôt change any data at all

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: we send the user input direct to mm

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: and display the mm output directly in the UI

Author: blackjok3r#0000
Content: ok no worries. Better docs were always a must, I tried to make some a few times, but things kept changing so fast I just gave up.

Author: blackjok3r#0000
Content: I think @Alright is doing it now though.

Author: imylomylo#0000
Content: yep <@U8MLQ662K> is on the case and has plenty of experience with mm.   new kmd team member <@U9LBB4CTG> also working on collating docs.  <@U02QSHX81> has a pretty good idea of what is going on in that regard coming from a testers background and is the QA/Support keeping an eye on progress.

Author: jansako#0000
Content:
<@U7B8VF6TB> I was on a va(work)cation for a couple of weeks, just lurking mostly. 
I am inclined to think that if the 'Requested' and 'Broadcast' entries are so different, maybe the 'Requested' entry (which shows 'incorrect' ) should not be shown at all? Then all you have is the 'Broadcast' and 'Executed' side, and once it is made clear in help/documentation that the 'broadcast' side will be always a bit different from what the user enters into the trade request boxes and why, the whole issue just goes away. 
Same goes for the 'The executed price was 4% cheaper than requested' line. A nice marketing touch, but kinda defeats the purpose if in 50% of the cases it shows an incorrect value üôÇ. 
The related github issues are closed, but I am happy to add my thoughts if <@U8MLQ662K> is making a new one.
Thanks guys!

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: We can continue discussion in the closed issue, no need to create a new one

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: https://github.com/lukechilds/hyperdex/issues/184

Author: lukechilds123#0000
Content: we can re-open if there‚Äôs a good solution

Author: phideas#0000
Content: Executed trade is correct, so no big issue. But the displayed "requested" info is wrong. It should be simply fixed on UI level. I wouldn't remove it entirely b/c it is very useful.

Author: jansako#0000
Content:
the 'simply fixed on the UI level' is the real issue here üôÇ. It would require a design decision to start 'interpreting' MM data instead of simply displaying it as is done now. There are very valid arguments for doing it and not doing it as well. 
Like I said above, I tend to go for axing a feature, even if just temporarily, if I can't implement it correctly...
